data.text: Light Color Long Sleeve Jerseys for Hot Weather BikePacking
Hey group—question. I’m looking for a light color (to reflect heat) long sleeve jersey (sun protection) for gravel/bikepacking in hot weather. Any favorites?
Check sun shirts, from many different outdoor clothing companies, Patagonia, NRS, Core Concepts, Stio, TNF, OR, Marmot, and more .
data.author: Toby Homsher

data.text: I like buying the long sleeve light weight shirts from Duluth. They are inexpensive button Downs made from wiki material and the sleeves can pin up when needed. I tend to wear these at work hiking and biking whatever
data.author: Tony Dangerfield

data.text: I’ve gone to sun sleeves in white. Pearl Izumi and others make them.
data.author: Robin Verner

data.text: I wear an Underarmour Heatgear long sleeved top if I want something close fitting. It’s also rated for sun protection. If I want something looser, I wear a sun shirt. If I want to wear a jersey, I wear sun sleeves with an SPF rating.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: They get stinky fast, but in hit weather I use a skin tight, lightweight racing jersy designed to wick sweat away. When moving I really feel the cooling effect. I wear lightweight solar sleeves on my arms too - mostly for sun protection
data.author: Mike Kehoe

data.text: long sleeve cotton shirt. cheapest you can find. Cotton will soak up your sweat and say wet, keeping you cool. It will also stink a lot less than any synthetic will.
data.author: Seth McFarland

data.text:
Check out crankstyle.com. Their jerseys are light, wicking and awesome for sun sleeves.
Crank Style - Your One Stop Shop for High Quality Cycling Gear
crankstyle.com
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: Look for LS fishing shirts. Nice range of movement, good spf rating, cool (with back vents). I find them on marketplace all the time
data.author: Tim Schurr

data.text: I like to go to outdoor outlet stores, like Columbia or Eddie Bauer, and buy their long sleeve button-up, collar shirts. They are lightweight and fairly inexpensive. As for the sun protection, I am not sure...but give it a shot. Also, I know REI has shirts - but much more expensive. On the Youtube channel, Path Less Pedaled, he talks about buying fishing shirts (I think) bc of the lightweight, inexpensive, etc. Search for "bike clothing" - lots of vids.
data.author: Lee Young-il

data.text:
I prefer sun hoodies. My favorite is probably this one: https://www.exofficio.com/men/tops/sweaters-and-hoodies/mens-sol-cool-bayview-hoodie/AFS_195116032820.html
Men's Sol Cool™ Bayview Hoodie | ExOfficio
exofficio.com
data.author: Justin Ammerman

data.text: Showers pass wool tech shirts, come in long sleeve and short. Don’t stink and work great. Sun sleeves with short sleeve is great combo
data.author: Brian Steven Wagner

data.text: I personally use Columbia/etc "fishing" shirts. Very lightweight, cooling, breathable and not too stupidly expensive
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: I love the Columbia PFG long sleeve fly fishing shirts Brandi noted. SPF 50, breezy, dry quickly, can roll sleeves up, has pockets up front, and often have prints that hide the dirt well. I’m wearing one in my profile pic. Often 30-40% off retail when on sale. I add a wool base layer for cool mornings and evenings and can wash out the shirt at night for a clean dry shirt in about an hour.
data.author: Jim Lee

data.text: Outdoor Research Echo hoodie or long-sleeved T. You often see them come up on Last Hunt for <$50
data.author: Mark Hohmann
